segments.text: All the opponents of nuclear power have reinforced it.
Now they have made it so difficult that I don't know whether Three Mile Island will get started up or not.
If it does, it will cost them so much that it'll distort the whole picture insofar as the economics of nuclear power are concerned.
All or nothing.

they it ought to be a wonderful lesson to us i think we ought to feel we ought to feel great about nuclear power as a result of three mile island because did all the things wrong that you could hardly do wrong and still the thing took care of itself and uh it's gonna well i'd like to see it back in operation okay now let's go back into history and i would like to know about uh
more technical question.
What was the size of the staff that you had at the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project?
How large was the bureaucracy?
Let's see.
I had about 200 people in Washington at the headquarters.
And I had about 500 people at Sandia base.
And maybe another 50 that was scattered Los Alamos, Little Moore, Rocky Flats, other sites, Arco, Nevada.
And then had a contingence of troops and maintenance people at all of the weapons storage sites.
And that depended upon the size of the site and what had to be guarded.
So it was like 3,000.
troops out at the site, troops and maintenance personnel.
Now can you tell me about the relations that you had, oh well first, were those 3,000, how many were civilians and how many were military?
All of the people at the sites were military.
All of them at Sandia were military, except maybe fifty.
Those in headquarters in Washington, they were about one-third, or about two-thirds military.
I'm not talking about clerks and secretaries.
I'm talking about the professional people.
Now, how good were the relations between the professionals, civilians, and the military administration?
Very, very good.
Very good.
Most of the military people that we had in Opswap, and in AEC for that matter,
who were concerned with command functions or technical functions, where personnel were qualified technically to about the same level that the people were in AEC.
We had many of them with PhDs, lots of them with masters.
We had nuclear
physicists, astrophysicists, very highly qualified military personnel.
So the relationship was very, very good.
One thing that I was wondering about is that, well, they just retired Admiral Rickover, and I was wondering if you worked on the submarine project and the development of the nuclear subs.
Even though, of course, this is Air Force versus Navy, but still.
Well, I worked on it in about three senses, three manners.
One in the Military Liaison Committee.
I worked with Rickover, whose office was right next door in the AEC, in helping him get on with the early stages of it.

Then later, in Armed Forces Special Weapons Project, we had very little to do with effects of a good many of the things that were going on in the submarines, and particularly as it related to placing nuclear weapons in submarines.
So, we did quite a bit of work with them on that.
Later on, when I took over the general manager of the commission, of course, he was head of the nuclear submarine division of the reactor development division of the staff.
And so in that capacity was under the general manager.
And so he submitted his programs to me and budgets, and they were all blended into the reactor development budget and the commission budget and defended before the Congress and wherever.
And of course, Rickover was quite good before the Congress in his own defense, but it takes more than Rickover to get his money.
So for the six years that I was there, I defended his budget before the Congress, as did he.
So I was fairly deeply involved.
I've got a whole bunch of pictures in there of the launching of one of the subs in which I participated.
Rickover has his friends and his critics in Congress, and he's just been in forced retirement.
It's been said that he was very difficult to get along with, especially if you were on the wrong side of him.
What was your relationship like?
What type of person did you think he was?
Well, I think there's no such thing as getting along with Rickover, for anybody, not for me or for anybody else.
The question is...
just how badly do you get tangled up with him, and can you go ahead and accomplish what both of you are trying to accomplish in spite of that fact?
And I think I was able to do that.
So I think if Rick and I were talking, we'd say the same things about each other.
I'd have a little different emphasis than he does.
And I have a great deal of respect for his abilities and capabilities in a number of areas.
And in some other areas, I think he's nuts.
I suspect he'd say the same thing about me.
In spite of the fact that he
is very, very good and has done a wonderful job, I think, overall for the nation in creating a nuclear subsurface navy.
And I think he has done that.
I think he's done a lot of damage to particular to other aspects of the armed forces.
For example?
For the surface Navy is one example.
I'm sure the Secretary of the Navy or the Black Shoe Admirals are not a damn bit happy about a lot of the things he's doing.
I'm sure of it.
He has pressed the contractors, Rick has,
the electric boat, the other people who do the work, but more particularly their subcontractor, to the point that it's just almost impossible to work with them.
Well, you can't condemn all of that, because, and part of it, Rick, is perfectly right, and it's shameful, the thing that they get by with.
But it's not all of them, all of the time.
There has to be an accommodation so you can get on with your job.
But his is a fight from daylight till dark with any contractor that he's working with.
Most of the naval officers that work with him, manning the submarines,
just, just can hardly stomach it at all.
That's not 100% true, but, but I'll know.
My son-in-law in the Navy was called in, in a group by Rick to, because he got, got his choice of the top young officers of the Navy as of any particular time.
There for some
And he was an engineering officer, my son-in-law, and I called him in and examined his qualifications along with others in that same group.
And he was particularly belligerent to Rickover on that thing and got turned down.
I haven't seen a happier young man in my life, and I found out he got turned down.
He didn't go in there because he sure didn't want anything.
It must have been difficult having him for a subordinate, having Rickover for a subordinate.
I could usually agree with
with the things that were the Commission's responsibility in his job.
And he was answering, of course, to the Department of Defense in his other hat.
And that's where the real problem was.
Because ours was essentially research and development on various aspects of the reactor itself.
the procurement of that reactor and its installation and the submarine and the submarine contract and all that was, that was a defense problem.
And I'm sure I couldn't have gotten along with him if I'd had all that responsibility.
But we gave him support in the nuclear side of the thing and we were able to agree on what the budget should be and how he should run it overall.
And having done that and got it through Congress, I could turn it over to him, and then all I had to do was audit it after that, because he ran it okay, no problem.
So there was not such a tremendous area of disagreement for us to get at each other's throat about.
So we got along fine.
And I admire Rickover in a lot of ways.
I think he thinks he knows too damn much about too many things, and I think it's always dangerous when a guy gets himself into that frame of mind.
He's an authority on education, among other things.
He's written a couple of books I have in there on education, what's wrong with American education.

Whether I like him or don't like him, or whether I like his characteristics or don't like them, or whether I think he ought to be in the Navy until he's 82 or retired 20 years ago, I still have to face the fact that he has been consistent and persistent enough that we, the United States, have a damn good underwater naval capability.
it badly.
And without Rick, I'm not sure we'd have it.
And so, whatever else I might think about it, I'm thankful that he was there.
How did he ever stay in the Navy until he was 82?
He stayed there by one mechanism.
He convinced the
the Joint Committee of the Congress, Joint Committee on Atomic Energy of the Congress, that he was right and the Navy was wrong, and they promoted him the first time.
They forced the Navy to promote him and kept him on there.
He took advantage of that, and he kept the Congress
fully informed at all times, Congress being the joint committee primarily.

And he became very close friends of people who were chairmen of the joint committee, Senator Anderson from New Mexico and Congressman Holifield from California, who kind of alternated the chairmanship.
He became a very close friend of Senator Cannon from Missouri, head of the Appropriations Committee.
And Senator Cannon ran that goddamn Congress for a mighty long time.
And there didn't anybody dispute his authority either.
And this carried on.
So it's the Congress that has kept Rick
in his job.
They've supported his program.
They've listened to him talk.
We've gotten somewhat of a kick out of it, and they have forced the Navy to keep him on.
They had to promotethe Congress promoted him from captain to rear admiral, and they promoted him to vice admiral, and they have kept him on active duty all this time.
Not the Department of Defense, but the Congress.
And he's used everything in his power to do that, even capitalizing a little bit on the fact that he's Jewish and a little anti-Semitism that somebody can dream up.
He's pretty good at some of these things.
You heard him yesterday talking to Proxmire, I guess, and telling him about it.
Well, that's your fault.
You gave them the money.
I wanted to have just your opinion on the neutron bomb.
I mean, whether we should have it or not?
Well, yes, the neutron bomb is not new.
No.
people thought about it even before I was involved in the atomic energy business.
And that principle has been under test for quite a long time.
And it was finally developed so that it, as a practical weapon, could be used.
And its effect has been explained.
So it becomes now a question of, is that an effect that we need in our arsenal in the current position we're in in the world vis-a-vis the Soviet Union?
And I think the answer to that is clearly yes.
I think we ought to make it and stockpile it, regardless of what the hell anybody else thinks.
And if a time ever comes that we need to use it in our own interest, use it, whether anybody else likes it or not.
Because Western Europe, Italy, or I shouldn't cite Italy, any of them over there,
We're going to be hauling louder than anybody else if the time comes and we need to use it and we don't have it.
How come you didn't have it?
So it's a good weapon and it's for a good purpose.
It's one we need in our arsenal and I think we ought to get on with it.
Okay.
Now I want to go back and I want to ask you about the development of storage sites for atomic weapons.
At first we didn't have any atomic weapons and then we started to develop them.
What were the problems with building storage sites?
How did we pick storage sites?
Well, there were really two major problems initially I'm talking about.

One was how did one store these so that it would be almost impossible for anyone to get access to them, either to take them, that is, take them because we're the only ones in the world who had them at that time, take them from a secrecy standpoint,
And how could you prevent access to them by anyone who wanted to use them for some other purpose, such as terror or blackmail or whatnot?
And how could you protect them from a major situation in which there was limited invasion or insurrection or something in which there was a force available to try to take them by force?
And of course, the other thing, the other major consideration at the time
Under what conditions do you store them so that if there was an accidental detonation, the least amount of damage would be done?
Damage to people, to the surrounding country, to the installation itself, to any other weapon that you would have?

So the answer to all of these, the best answer anyone could come up with, turned out to be cutting back into mountains, into solid rock, with chambers to store these under controlled conditions of humidity, temperature, and this sort of thing.
Places where they could be secured
individually in their compartments, in an area that was large enough that if something happened to this one, the one next to it wouldn't be affected, and so on.
And then to enclose the entire area and guard it in a manner to deny access
to the site, even though people presumably when they got on site couldn't get into the individual storage locations.
So this was, that's the way it was accomplished.
Now are these sites, are they top secret, or can you tell me where some of those are?
No, I don't know.
what their classification are now.
As a matter of fact, I don't even know where they are now.
So they've changed over the years?
That's good.
Oh, yeah.
Why do they change them?
I mean, if they have a successful site or one that's secure.
Well, they haven't changed them all.
I don't mean that.
They've produced a lot of weapons since I got out of the business, so I don't know where they have put them.
And that's good, I don't want them.
But they are located usually within a few miles of locations from which they're going to be used.
Oh, I see.
from the major missile launch areas, from the major sack areas, from the major attack areas.
So there are a number of sites.
I built five while I was in Nashua because it was our job to find them, build them, occupy them, take custody of weapons and put them in them and see that they stay there.
see that they were maintained and ready to go.
So I built five of the five.
The one everyone knows about, I suspect, is near Albuquerque, the first one.
It's still there, and I'm sure it's still occupied.
Now, why did you leave the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project?
Was your tour of duty on?
Yes, it was.
See I had been in there nearly six years, about that.
And I had been the deputy and then I became the chief and it was time to do something else.
Well, were you happy with your next assignment as the commander, Joint Task Force 7, Nuclear Test Organization?
Yes, very.
Very.
Yeah, it was a very good assignment, a very, very rough problem.
One that would be extremely difficult to handle.
Now, why were you only there a year?
because that's how long it took to do it.
We finished the job.
Okay.
Let's talk about that.
What were your responsibilities?
The Joint Task Force, in this case Joint Task Force Seven, has the job of testing
overseas, it doesn't operate within the United States, such weapons and devices as the Atomic Energy Commission and the Secretary of Defense might direct.
This one was primarily a development test program to be conducted and
primarily in Inuitak, although also included Bikini and Kwajalein, and as it turned out, Johnson Island, before we got through.
The emphasis of the testing was on

medium- and high-yield thermonuclear devices to determine their characteristics and decide which ones would go into production for what purposes and in what configurations, as well as to get a number of weapons effects, many of the weapons effects.
two of the detonations were to be conducted at high altitude, primarily for effects purposes, although we were also testing the devices.
And they worked.
I've forgotten how many tests were conducted in that series, but it was like 38 or 40.
What were the majorwhat did you learn from these tests?
The major?
What did you learn from these tests and the new information?
From the standpoint of development of the weapons, it is so highly technical and is a space and time there that I would have to go back and refresh myself to be specific about.
But we moved to stockpile after those tests.

with several warheads that were firmed up as a result of those taps, so that we knew exactly what their configuration was, exactly what their yield was, and exactly what their effects were, so that we could then
put them into a weapons system, establish those weapons characteristics, and go to production.
That was, of course, the real big achievement of the test series.
We had many weapons effects programs that either confirmed or developed a
information we needed to further our weapons effects business.
And the one at high altitude gave us the effects on the ionosphere and on the atmosphere and answered many technical questions.
I think eliminated the need for further testing up there and certainly took away any doubts about what it did.
One thing I wanted to ask was what weapon systems, new weapon systems resulted from
your test at Joint Task Force 7.
Can you talk about that?
I think that there probably were none that you could say this resulted directly from this test.
Weapons systems take many years and many considerations and probably usually many tests.
And so while this one
conform many aspects or develop many new planning factors and things like that.
As far as I can remember right now, it didn't develop a particular weapon system.
It cannot come as a result of one test.
It gave us the information we needed to make the decisions as to what warheads to put on several weapons and weapons systems.
But of course it's only one element of such a decision.
Why did you retire?
From the Air Force?
Yes.
Well, I was asked to take this job as general manager of AEC by people that I had a great deal of respect for.
Mr. Strauss, who was chairman of the AEC at that time, Louis Strauss, and John McCone, who was
coming in to be chairman shortly, and by President Eisenhower, who was president at the time.
And it was a, to me, a real challenge in terms of my earlier decisions and earlier experience.
And I wanted to know whether I could do something outside of the military because I hadn't had really an opportunity to find out.
So I debated it hard and finally decided to do it.
Whether it was a good thing to do, I haven't any idea because
I went to see General White, who was Chief of Staff of the Air Force at that time, to see if he would honor my request for early retirement.
He entreated me not to do it, and pointed out that I wasn't doing so bad in the Air Force, which I certainly had to agree with.
there were a number of new assignments and promotions coming up right then, right immediately.
And I feel sure that I would have been one of them had I stayed in.
Of course, what the field doesn't amount to very much, because I understand you don't know the answer to it, but I think I would have been
placed in either the Logistics Command or the Development Command and promoted to three stars probably by the end of that year.
But I didn't stay for that.
I decided to go ahead and retire early and take this other job because you cannot, by law, occupy that position, statutory position.
while you retain your status as an active duty officer in the armed services.
So I had to retire in order to qualify under the law to take the job.
Do you regret retiring?
Do you regret retiring?
You might have been able to make four stars.
You certainly were young enough.
I feel confident that I would have.
I was young enough and I was in the right spot and I had the right head start and everything else, so I think yes, I would have made four stars all right.
I wouldn't have had a lot of the experiences that I had.
I might have had some that were more interesting, I don't know, but I doubt it.
But I don't regret anything.
in that respect.
I have to look back and say that's the decision and I went on and did the best I could in light of that decision and that I think was
credible and very interesting, so I don't regret it.
Can you tell me about your retirement ceremony?
There really wasn't one, because I was not in Washington at the time when there could have been a
but they had normally over at Bowling Air Force Base.
And the change was being made in the commission, or had been made, chairman change.
And because I couldn't get there in time, they had a man acting in my place as general manager and were anxious for me to get on board.
So I went right from the Joint Task Force one day to the AEC the next day and took over General Manager.
There weren't all retirement ceremonies.
Let's talk about this job as General Manager.
How large was the AEC at this time?
What size, what type of responsibilities are we discussing?
Well, AACSNO operated with a minimum number of government personnel and a major effort with contractors.
So, I think it would be almost impossible to
We have a number of people in contractors, but if we took the three points, about 4,000 people in AEC, a little over $4 billion budget, and like 300,000 people under contract.
That would give a measure of magnitude.
That's about what it was.
This is more a responsibility than you ever had in your life then.
Yes.
Did you enjoy the new position?
Well, enjoy is perhaps not the right word.
It was so big, so quick.
that I didn't have time for anything except work and keep my head above water.
I took the job the first of December 1958.
Congress back in session by early January and four billion dollars worth of budget to defend
It takes a lot of doing.
And so I would really cover it up very fast.
And of course, the activities are still going full underway while you defend the budget.
So operating problems were terrific.
And of course, I was new to the commission.
The people in it who were operating didn't know my policies or my views or whatnot.
So it was a really hectic, busy time for me.
I spent about 15, 16 hours a day at it for the first year at least.
I want to talk about the issues or the major problems in the AEC at that time that you were directly involved with.
What were some of the issues or headaches?
Well, they
Promotion of application of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes, of course, is the primary mission.
And everywhere you turn there are people fighting this objective.
So just keeping the fires put out was a hell of a job all by itself.
Are these people the environmentalists?
Well, it includes those.
It's not limited to those.
It includes all kinds of people.
One group that's particularly troublesome that it includes is a bunch of so-called scientists, or people who call themselves scientists.
They haven't been really successful on the positive side.
So they go to the negative side to make themselves heard.
And some of them work for you, you, the commission.
This creates real troublesome problems.
What was your question directed?
We were talking about the issues and the problems.
One you said were the scientists.
That went across the board, of course.
The real issues were on the positive side, of course, with power reactors, development of power reactors, power applications.
At the same time, we were developing the ram chip for military application.
Isotopes, tremendous amount of work with isotopes.
We're getting started well on fusion power, about 30 million a year on that at that time.
The increase in capacity of the diffusion plants
Which is a really major problem.
And electricity or power for those plants.
Because at one time we were using one-tenth of all the power generated in the United States.
No kidding.
That's a pretty big magnitude of thing.
That's for sure.
And weapons and weapons testing, of course.
It was always there and it was always a really big issue in one form or another the whole time.
That covers an awful lot of ground that I've just said there.

Those could be broken down into dozens and dozens of issues, such as providing the facilities for high energy physics and low energy physics, the roles of the universities and educational institutions.
in the AC.
How did Texas A&M get a cyclotron, for example?
That came out of this consideration during that time.
Well, let's start in on some of these.
What about Plowshare?
Placere was another of the issues here, and of course Placere was the use of nuclear explosives for peaceful purposes.
Our primary effort there was directed at the use of the explosives to move earth, such as you would do to dig a new Panama Canal, for example.
And by the time I left the commission and the program closed down shortly after that, the techniques and technology had been developed adequately to use nuclear explosives to do many peaceful things.
It's never possible to remove all of the radioactivity and the other considerations that go with it from that process.
And with the rising opposition to nuclear...
